name: Regulation of Ca++ and Phosphate

# Regulation of Ca<sup>++</sup> and Phosphate

The parathyroid glands monitor and respond to circulating levels of Ca<sup>++</sup> in the blood. When levels drop too low, PTH is released to stimulate the DCT to reabsorb Ca<sup>++ </sup>from the forming urine. When levels are adequate or high, less PTH is released and more Ca<sup>++</sup> remains in the forming urine to be lost. Phosphate levels move in the opposite direction. When Ca<sup>++</sup> levels are low, PTH inhibits reabsorption of <math display="left" xmlns:q="http://cnx.rice.edu/qml/1.0" xmlns:m="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:bib="http://bibtexml.sf.net/" xmlns:md="http://cnx.rice.edu/mdml" xmlns="http://cnx.rice.edu/cnxml"> <semantics>  <mrow>   <msubsup>    <mrow>     <mtext>HPO</mtext>    </mrow>    <mn>4</mn>    <mrow>     <mn>2</mn><mo>âˆ’</mo>    </mrow>   </msubsup>     </mrow>  <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3AF7@</annotation> </semantics></math>
 so that its blood level drops, allowing Ca<sup>++</sup> levels to rise. PTH also stimulates the renal conversion of calcidiol into calcitriol, the active form of vitamin D. Calcitriol then stimulates the intestines to absorb more Ca<sup>++</sup> from the diet.
